<p><strong>The flow control sector,</strong> which is part of the broader industrials sector, consists of companies that provide products or services involving the management and control of liquids and gases. Such products include pumps, valves, compressors, meters, filtration products, and other related equipment. These are some of the most critical and prevalent components in modern industries. Comprising three core segmentsâflow handing, flow management, and specialty equipmentâthe sector represented a global market worth $225 billion in revenue in 2017 (Exhibit 1) and has outperformed the broader industrials sector over the past 15 years.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/advanced%20electronics/our%20insights/flow%20control%20sector%20at%20a%20crossroads/svgz-flowcontrol-ex1-vf2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Flow control equipment generates approximately $225 billion in global revenue." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/advanced%20electronics/our%20insights/flow%20control%20sector%20at%20a%20crossroads/svgz-flowcontrol-ex1-vf2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>However, performance has plateaued in recent years, and as the flow control sector looks to the future, it finds itself at a crossroads. Has the sectorâs performance reached a ceiling? Or can it leverage favorable secular trends of rising demand for infrastructure driven by rapid urbanization in emerging markets and an overhaul of aging infrastructure in developed markets, and of technology disruptions in areas such as the <a href="/capabilities/operations/our-insights/operations-blog/unlock-value-with-an-industrial-iot-technology-stack-that-scales">Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT)</a>, automation, and <a href="/featured-insights/artificial-intelligence">artificial intelligence</a> to break out of recent stagnation and drive the next phase of value expansion for its stakeholders?</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>Sector pulse check: Executive survey</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>To understand the pulse of the sector, we surveyed more than 40 executives in flow control, focusing on their outlook for the sector, upcoming opportunities for growth, and their preparedness to secure these opportunities. Weâve distilled the results into four key findings.</p>
<h3>1. Flow control leaders are optimistic about the sectorâs future</h3>
<p>More than 80 percent of the executives we surveyed think that flow control performance sentiments have improved in the past year, and almost 60 percent believe the sector will grow faster than GDP (Exhibit 1).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/advanced%20electronics/our%20insights/flow%20control%20sector%20at%20a%20crossroads/svgz-flowcontrol-sidebarex1-vf2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="The majority of flow control executives surveyed believe that sector sentiments have improved in the past 12 months. " src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/advanced%20electronics/our%20insights/flow%20control%20sector%20at%20a%20crossroads/svgz-flowcontrol-sidebarex1-vf2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<h3>2. New technologies and geographic expansion will provide new growth opportunities</h3>
<p>Three-quarters of our survey respondents agreed that new technologies offer the biggest opportunities for growth (Exhibit 2). Traditionally, flow control companies have lagged behind in their adoption of technology and reactions to new trends as most companies have been able to thrive on high margins and specialization. Now, however, executives recognize the need to embrace change and make moves in new areas. Growing interest in technology and innovation is also demonstrated by increasing acquisitions of IoT, data analytics, and software start-ups among large flow control companies.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/advanced%20electronics/our%20insights/flow%20control%20sector%20at%20a%20crossroads/svgz-flowcontrol-sidebarex2-vf2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Flow control executives recognize that new technologies and geographical expansion present the biggest opportunities." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/advanced%20electronics/our%20insights/flow%20control%20sector%20at%20a%20crossroads/svgz-flowcontrol-sidebarex2-vf2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<h3>3. Executives know what they need to doâbut they feel unprepared</h3>
<p>Most executives agreed that they need to expand their offerings, particularly by focusing on smarter products; offer a full solution for their customers; and improve their capabilities by incorporating advanced analytics into their approach. These changes in turn require them to make different operating-model choices so they can be more agile both in their own decision making and in serving customers (Exhibit 3).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 3</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/advanced%20electronics/our%20insights/flow%20control%20sector%20at%20a%20crossroads/svgz-flowcontrol-sidebarex3-vf2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="To capture new opportunities, executives believe they will need new enablers, especially âsmarterâ or IoT-enabled products, full solutions, and new service models." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/advanced%20electronics/our%20insights/flow%20control%20sector%20at%20a%20crossroads/svgz-flowcontrol-sidebarex3-vf2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>While executives recognize that they need to take advantage of new opportunities, few feel ready. In our survey, only a small percentage of companies (10 to 15 percent) had made significant progress in developing new operating models and capabilities. More executives (33 percent) responded that theyâd made significant progress in developing new offerings, but the number is still fairly low given the potential of the opportunities (Exhibit 4).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 4</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/advanced%20electronics/our%20insights/flow%20control%20sector%20at%20a%20crossroads/svgz-flowcontrol-sidebarex4-vf2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="While sector growth will provide significant opportunites, industry executives feel underprepared to capitalize on these opportunties." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/advanced%20electronics/our%20insights/flow%20control%20sector%20at%20a%20crossroads/svgz-flowcontrol-sidebarex4-vf2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<h3>4. Focus on short-term investments, lack of a burning platform, and difficulty finding the right talent are proving to be this sectorâs Achillesâ heel</h3>
<p>When asked whatâs holding them back, executives said the greatest challenge comes from companiesâ reluctance to make bold betsâ28 percent suggested that shorter-term investments are taking a higher priority, 23 percent cited the lack of a burning platform to act quickly, and 19 percent found it difficult to find the right talent to drive the priorities (Exhibit 5).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 5</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/advanced%20electronics/our%20insights/flow%20control%20sector%20at%20a%20crossroads/svgz-flowcontrol-sidebarex5-vf2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="The greatest challenge for flow control companies attempting to develop new enablers is prioritizing long-term bold bets when short-term investments provide quicker returns." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/advanced%20electronics/our%20insights/flow%20control%20sector%20at%20a%20crossroads/svgz-flowcontrol-sidebarex5-vf2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Against this backdrop, we set out to better understand the forces at work. This effort resulted in a new report, <em>Flow controlâSector at a crossroads?</em> It provides an in-depth assessment of the sectorâs performance over the past 15 years, the shifting dynamics affecting its future, and how the current playbooks will need to be adapted to capture future opportunities and drive the next phase of value expansion. The remainder of this article outlines some of our high-level findings. (For more on our research base, see sidebar, âSector pulse check: Executive survey.â)</p>
<h2>Historical performance in flow control</h2>
<p>The industrials sector has demonstrated value-accretive growth through three distinct performance phases from 2002 to 2017: rapid growth, slump and recovery, and a dip and potential recovery. Throughout each phase, the flow control sector has outperformed the broader industrials sector and in 2017 had twice the economic profit as a share of revenue (EP/R) compared with industrials as a whole (3.0 percent versus 1.5 percent) (Exhibit 2).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/advanced%20electronics/our%20insights/flow%20control%20sector%20at%20a%20crossroads/svgz-flowcontrol-ex2-vf2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="The flow control sector has consistently outperformed broader industrials on economic profit as share of revenue." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/advanced%20electronics/our%20insights/flow%20control%20sector%20at%20a%20crossroads/svgz-flowcontrol-ex2-vf2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>The consistent outperformance reflects the sectorâs high gross marginâapproximately 500 basis points (bps) higher than the average of broader industrialsâand the fact that flow control products are highly specialized in nature, as many are engineered for specific or unique uses. In addition, flow control companies have established significant market share in small end markets, resulting in higher pricing power.</p>
<p>While flow control as a whole has notched strong performance on key economic indicators, there is significant variance in company performance within the segments (Exhibit 3). In fact, across the three segments, the EP/R performance gap between leading and trailing companies was between 1,300 and 1,800 bps.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 3</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/advanced%20electronics/our%20insights/flow%20control%20sector%20at%20a%20crossroads/svgz-flowcontrol-ex3-vf2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Within each segment of flow control there was a 1,300 to 1,800 basis point spread in economic profit as a share of revenue  performance across companies." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/advanced%20electronics/our%20insights/flow%20control%20sector%20at%20a%20crossroads/svgz-flowcontrol-ex3-vf2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Our research shows companies in the top quartile comprehensively outperformed their peers on all output metrics:</p>
<ul>
    <li>higher revenue growth: 2.2 percent for the top quartile, versus â3.1 percent for their lowest-performing peers</li>
    <li>higher earnings before interest, taxes, and amortization (EBITA): 23.3 percent versus 7.8 percent</li>
    <li>better operating leverage: 18.4 percentage points versus â20.5 percentage points</li>
    <li>higher capital turnover: 2.29 turns versus 1.73 turns</li>
</ul>
<p>Interestingly, flow control company performance has not been static: 60 percent of companies moved across quartile rankings between 2002â07 and 2012â17. In that time frame, 30 percent of players moved up from a lower quartile; a similar amount were displaced from a higher quartile.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-12"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>Would you like to learn more about our <a href="/industries/industrials-and-electronics/how-we-help-clients">Advanced Electronics Practice</a>?</div></h3></div></header><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c mck-c-disruptor1up__content Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__content--links__VV4lE mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="/industries/industrials-and-electronics/how-we-help-clients/robotics-and-industrial-automation" class="mdc-c-link-cta___NBQVi_990311c"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Visit our Industrial Technologies page</span><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mck-link-arrow-right-icon"></span></a></div></div></div></div>
<p>What made the difference for top-quartile companies? Analyzing company attributes and strategies, we found that neither a companyâs starting size nor its capital expenditures had a major influence on its EP/R performance. Rather, our research indicates that companies that stayed in the top quartile or improved their performance over time did so by focusing on quality of revenue, innovating across three dimensions:</p>
<ul>
    <li><em>product:</em> driving fundamental or core R&D, conducting frequent new product introduction, and rationalizing the portfolio</li>
    <li><em>operational excellence:</em> deploying capital to gain leadership, instilling process discipline in operations, and pushing innovation in operations</li>
    <li><em>business model:</em> building platforms and ecosystems to create recurring and âcost freeâ revenues and leveraging scale to drive customer value and capture a portion of it</li>
</ul>
<p>Although the flow control sector has consistently outperformed the rest of industrials, performance has started to plateau as EP/R has flattened and fewer companies have secured positive economic profit. This trend is prevalent throughout the sectorâtop-quartile companies have seen their EP/R flatten, while the remaining companies have seen a decline in EP/R and, in the past two years, negative economic profit (Exhibit 4).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 4</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/advanced%20electronics/our%20insights/flow%20control%20sector%20at%20a%20crossroads/svgz-flowcontrol-ex4-vf2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Recent performance for flow control companies has been flat, with negative economic profit as a share of revenue for companies in the bottom three quartiles." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/advanced%20electronics/our%20insights/flow%20control%20sector%20at%20a%20crossroads/svgz-flowcontrol-ex4-vf2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>In the past three years, we have also seen concentration in the sector, with only 35 percent of companies generating above-average economic profit, versus 45 percent of companies in the past. Thus, there are fewer winners and more are being left behind.</p>
<h2>The outlook for the flow control sector</h2>
<p>Still, the sectorâs future continues to be bright. Prospects are driven by demand growth as global secular trends continue to create demand tailwinds for flow control equipment; moreover, the emergence of disruptive technologies can help companies innovate further.</p>
<h3>Demand growth from secular trends</h3>
<p>Our analysis suggests that the market will grow at approximately 4.0 percent per annum, compared with approximately 2.3 percent from 2012 to 2017. This will be driven by five global trends:</p>
<ol>
    <li><em>Geographic trends.</em> Rapid urbanization in developing economies is expected to increase the population of <a href="/featured-insights/future-of-cities">cities</a> by 20 percent by 2025. This will have significant effects on infrastructure requirements in developing countries such as India and China and in regions such as Africa and Southeast Asia, creating geographic-expansion opportunities for flow control companies.</li>
    <li><em>Capital-expenditure outlook.</em> In addition to increased spending on infrastructure in developing markets, infrastructure capital expenditures are expected to grow globally by approximately 3.2 percent, reaching nearly $10 trillion by 2022. Significant growth momentum is expected from investments in sectors such as water infrastructure and <a href="/capabilities/operations/our-insights/reinventing-construction-through-a-productivity-revolution">construction</a>.</li>
    <li><em>Social trends.</em> An aging population and aging workforce will create <a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/closing-the-future-skills-gap">new skills gaps</a> for companies, particularly in the oil and gas and power and utilities sectors, where hiring younger, digital-savvy workers is already a challenge. While automation will help companies address this skills gap, moving from manual processes to automation will require companies to invest in long-term solutions. Many flow control companies possess long-term domain knowledge and are critically involved in those end markets; they will therefore play a crucial role in this transition.</li>
    <li><em>Technology trends.</em> <a href="/capabilities/operations/our-insights/industry-4-0-demystified-leans-next-level">Industry 4.0</a> and the IIoT have completely reshaped market expectations, vastly expanding the amount of connectivity and data the industry requires to make decisions and automate processes. As these technologies mature, the industrials sector and flow control companies have the potential to create new internal and external applications, and these applications will then enable new value creation.</li>
    <li><em>Geopolitical trends.</em> Increasing sanctions and geopolitical tensions, as well as an escalating trade war and tariffs, will require companies to navigate new and frequently complex terrain, and to assess new opportunities as the industry landscape evolves. Further strain for flow control companies could be caused by a decrease in spending on infrastructure, slowing activity in construction, or another drop in oil and gas capital expenditures. Finally, an increasingly unpredictable political landscape will require players to aggressively maintain their competitive edge.</li>
</ol>
<p>These five trends, on balance, will expand the total addressable market for flow control equipment and demand for specialized products and services.</p>
<h3>Value generation from disruptive technologies</h3>
<p>Disruption 2.0 technologiesâsuch as artificial intelligence, machine learning, IIoT, <a href="/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/autonomous-driving-disruption-technology-use-cases-and-opportunities">autonomous driving</a>, and <a href="/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/blockchain-beyond-the-hype-what-is-the-strategic-business-value">blockchain</a>âare expected to change how industries approach their operations and business models. This phase of disruption will be characterized by automated activities, a step change in productivity, and new types of interactions with machines. Disruption 2.0 technologies are creating opportunities for companies to improve the economics of their existing business as well as to secure substantial growth. Flow control companies could benefit as well if they adopt these technologies. Companies that embrace disruption and innovate in three dimensionsâoperations, product portfolios, and business modelsâcould ultimately create higher-quality revenue and support the next phase of growth.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-4 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-5 Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__image___2Gc4"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture"><img alt="Tech-enabled transformation: The trillion-dollar opportunity for industrials" src="/~/media/mckinsey/business%20functions/mckinsey%20digital/our%20insights/tech%20enabled%20transformation/hero-flat-tech-enable-transformation.jpg?cq=50&mh=145&car=16:9&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-8 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-7"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>Tech-enabled transformation: The trillion-dollar opportunity for industrials</div></h3></div></header><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c mck-c-disruptor1up__content Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__content--links__VV4lE mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/tech-enabled-transformation" class="mdc-c-link-cta___NBQVi_990311c"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Read the issue</span><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mck-link-arrow-right-icon"></span></a></div></div></div></div>
<p>Companies that have already advanced on all three dimensions secured the highest quality of revenue and broke away from their peers by measures of financial performance. Progressing on all three dimensions is rare; most companies focus on one dimension to be recognized as an operations champion, product leader, or business-model innovator. The full report looks more deeply at what each type of company can do to excel.</p>
<h2>What does it take to win?</h2>
<p>The tailwinds driving the flow control sector will provide ample opportunity for companies equipped with the right enablers to outperform their peers and accrue value. However, companies that maintain the status quo will be left behind as the market changes. With innovation disrupting the sector, the old playbook will no longer suffice. Conversely, capturing value from these innovations will not be trivial. Going forward, companies must address four key imperatives to develop a winning strategy and scale up:</p>
<ol>
    <li><em>Close the operating performance gap to free up capital.</em> New technologies and solutions are critical to success in the new environment. However,
    technological development requires a significant investment in capabilities, infrastructure, change management, and talent. Flow control companies can free up cash for these investments by looking across the return-on-invested-capital (ROIC) tree for opportunities such as product portfolio and feature optimization, pricing, supply-chain optimization, and sourcing.</li>
    <li><em>Establish a pragmatic game plan to use disruptive technologies. </em>Innovation can be expensive. Disruption 2.0 technologies can help flow control companies improve quality of revenue by focusing across the axes of product innovation, new business models, and operational excellence. However, the associated investments are significant. A pragmatic game plan is necessary to ensure the highest ROIC.</li>
    <li><em>Broaden the M&A mandate. </em>Traditionally, M&A activities in flow control have focused on sector consolidation. For companies to pull ahead and capitalize on new trends and Disruption 2.0, they should broaden the focus of their M&A mandate to also fill gaps in technology and capabilities. M&A can provide a faster route to product-portfolio diversification, new business models, and technologies and capabilities such as advanced analytics.</li>
    <li><em>Establish robust governance and performance management. </em>Closing operating-performance gaps and delivering on investments in innovation is a multiyear transformation. Such undertakings field a high risk of going directionless and compromising significant capital. As flow control companies embark on this journey, they should reflect on three questions: Have we defined appropriate near-term milestones that will help us gauge progress against the end-state objectives? Are we <a href="/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/the-organization-blog/keys-to-unlocking-great-decision-making">agile in our decision making</a> so that we can reprioritize if our initial bets are not successful? Have we reserved sufficient senior-management attention to the cause?</li>
</ol>
<hr>
<p>Overall, flow control companies must keep pace with Industry 4.0, IIoT, and machine learning, and robustly engage with the changing demands of the global market. As innovation disrupts the sector, the old playbook will not suffice. Flow control companies that make the right moves stand to gain significant advantage in an exciting period of growth and disruption.</p>

But the best days may still be ahead for flow control, given increasing demand and technological advancements."},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2019-07-30T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe flow control sector,\u003c/strong\u003e which is part of the broader industrials sector, consists of companies that provide products or services involving the management and control of liquids and gases. Such products include pumps, valves, compressors, meters, filtration products, and other related equipment. These are some of the most critical and prevalent components in modern industries. Comprising three core segments\u0026mdash;flow handing, flow management, and specialty equipment\u0026mdash;the sector represented a global market worth $225 billion in revenue in 2017 (Exhibit 1) and has outperformed the broader industrials sector over the past 15 years.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eHowever, performance has plateaued in recent years, and as the flow control sector looks to the future, it finds itself at a crossroads. Has the sector\u0026rsquo;s performance reached a ceiling? Or can it leverage favorable secular trends of rising demand for infrastructure driven by rapid urbanization in emerging markets and an overhaul of aging infrastructure in developed markets, and of technology disruptions in areas such as the \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/operations-blog/unlock-value-with-an-industrial-iot-technology-stack-that-scales\"\u003eIndustrial Internet of Things (IIoT)\u003c/a\u003e, automation, and \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/artificial-intelligence\"\u003eartificial intelligence\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;to break out of recent stagnation and drive the next phase of value expansion for its stakeholders?\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Sidebar 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eAgainst this backdrop, we set out to better understand the forces at work. This effort resulted in a new report, \u003cem\u003eFlow control\u0026mdash;Sector at a crossroads?\u003c/em\u003e It provides an in-depth assessment of the sector\u0026rsquo;s performance over the past 15 years, the shifting dynamics affecting its future, and how the current playbooks will need to be adapted to capture future opportunities and drive the next phase of value expansion. The remainder of this article outlines some of our high-level findings. (For more on our research base, see sidebar, \u0026ldquo;Sector pulse check: Executive survey.\u0026rdquo;)\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eHistorical performance in flow control\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe industrials sector has demonstrated value-accretive growth through three distinct performance phases from 2002 to 2017: rapid growth, slump and recovery, and a dip and potential recovery. Throughout each phase, the flow control sector has outperformed the broader industrials sector and in 2017 had twice the economic profit as a share of revenue (EP/R) compared with industrials as a whole (3.0 percent versus 1.5 percent) (Exhibit 2).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eThe consistent outperformance reflects the sector\u0026rsquo;s high gross margin\u0026mdash;approximately 500 basis points (bps) higher than the average of broader industrials\u0026mdash;and the fact that flow control products are highly specialized in nature, as many are engineered for specific or unique uses. In addition, flow control companies have established significant market share in small end markets, resulting in higher pricing power.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhile flow control as a whole has notched strong performance on key economic indicators, there is significant variance in company performance within the segments (Exhibit 3). In fact, across the three segments, the EP/R performance gap between leading and trailing companies was between 1,300 and 1,800 bps.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 3]]\n\u003cp\u003eOur research shows companies in the top quartile comprehensively outperformed their peers on all output metrics:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003ehigher revenue growth: 2.2 percent for the top quartile, versus \u0026ndash;3.1 percent for their lowest-performing peers\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003ehigher earnings before interest, taxes, and amortization (EBITA): 23.3 percent versus 7.8 percent\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003ebetter operating leverage: 18.4 percentage points versus \u0026ndash;20.5 percentage points\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003ehigher capital turnover: 2.29 turns versus 1.73 turns\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eInterestingly, flow control company performance has not been static: 60 percent of companies moved across quartile rankings between 2002\u0026ndash;07 and 2012\u0026ndash;17. In that time frame, 30 percent of players moved up from a lower quartile; a similar amount were displaced from a higher quartile.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Disruptor1UP dis1]]\n\u003cp\u003eWhat made the difference for top-quartile companies? Analyzing company attributes and strategies, we found that neither a company\u0026rsquo;s starting size nor its capital expenditures had a major influence on its EP/R performance. Rather, our research indicates that companies that stayed in the top quartile or improved their performance over time did so by focusing on quality of revenue, innovating across three dimensions:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eproduct:\u003c/em\u003e driving fundamental or core R\u0026amp;D, conducting frequent new product introduction, and rationalizing the portfolio\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eoperational excellence:\u003c/em\u003e deploying capital to gain leadership, instilling process discipline in operations, and pushing innovation in operations\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003ebusiness model:\u003c/em\u003e building platforms and ecosystems to create recurring and \u0026ldquo;cost free\u0026rdquo; revenues and leveraging scale to drive customer value and capture a portion of it\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlthough the flow control sector has consistently outperformed the rest of industrials, performance has started to plateau as EP/R has flattened and fewer companies have secured positive economic profit. This trend is prevalent throughout the sector\u0026mdash;top-quartile companies have seen their EP/R flatten, while the remaining companies have seen a decline in EP/R and, in the past two years, negative economic profit (Exhibit 4).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 4]]\n\u003cp\u003eIn the past three years, we have also seen concentration in the sector, with only 35 percent of companies generating above-average economic profit, versus 45 percent of companies in the past. Thus, there are fewer winners and more are being left behind.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eThe outlook for the flow control sector\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eStill, the sector\u0026rsquo;s future continues to be bright. Prospects are driven by demand growth as global secular trends continue to create demand tailwinds for flow control equipment; moreover, the emergence of disruptive technologies can help companies innovate further.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eDemand growth from secular trends\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOur analysis suggests that the market will grow at approximately 4.0 percent per annum, compared with approximately 2.3 percent from 2012 to 2017. This will be driven by five global trends:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eGeographic trends.\u003c/em\u003e Rapid urbanization in developing economies is expected to increase the population of \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/future-of-cities\"\u003ecities\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;by 20 percent by 2025. This will have significant effects on infrastructure requirements in developing countries such as India and China and in regions such as Africa and Southeast Asia, creating geographic-expansion opportunities for flow control companies.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eCapital-expenditure outlook.\u003c/em\u003e In addition to increased spending on infrastructure in developing markets, infrastructure capital expenditures are expected to grow globally by approximately 3.2 percent, reaching nearly $10 trillion by 2022. Significant growth momentum is expected from investments in sectors such as water infrastructure and \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/reinventing-construction-through-a-productivity-revolution\"\u003econstruction\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eSocial trends.\u003c/em\u003e An aging population and aging workforce will create \u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/closing-the-future-skills-gap\"\u003enew skills gaps\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;for companies, particularly in the oil and gas and power and utilities sectors, where hiring younger, digital-savvy workers is already a challenge. While automation will help companies address this skills gap, moving from manual processes to automation will require companies to invest in long-term solutions. Many flow control companies possess long-term domain knowledge and are critically involved in those end markets; they will therefore play a crucial role in this transition.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eTechnology trends.\u003c/em\u003e \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/industry-4-0-demystified-leans-next-level\"\u003eIndustry 4.0\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;and the IIoT have completely reshaped market expectations, vastly expanding the amount of connectivity and data the industry requires to make decisions and automate processes. As these technologies mature, the industrials sector and flow control companies have the potential to create new internal and external applications, and these applications will then enable new value creation.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eGeopolitical trends.\u003c/em\u003e Increasing sanctions and geopolitical tensions, as well as an escalating trade war and tariffs, will require companies to navigate new and frequently complex terrain, and to assess new opportunities as the industry landscape evolves. Further strain for flow control companies could be caused by a decrease in spending on infrastructure, slowing activity in construction, or another drop in oil and gas capital expenditures. Finally, an increasingly unpredictable political landscape will require players to aggressively maintain their competitive edge.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThese five trends, on balance, will expand the total addressable market for flow control equipment and demand for specialized products and services.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eValue generation from disruptive technologies\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDisruption 2.0 technologies\u0026mdash;such as artificial intelligence, machine learning, IIoT, \u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/autonomous-driving-disruption-technology-use-cases-and-opportunities\"\u003eautonomous driving\u003c/a\u003e, and \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/blockchain-beyond-the-hype-what-is-the-strategic-business-value\"\u003eblockchain\u003c/a\u003e\u0026mdash;are expected to change how industries approach their operations and business models. This phase of disruption will be characterized by automated activities, a step change in productivity, and new types of interactions with machines. Disruption 2.0 technologies are creating opportunities for companies to improve the economics of their existing business as well as to secure substantial growth. Flow control companies could benefit as well if they adopt these technologies. Companies that embrace disruption and innovate in three dimensions\u0026mdash;operations, product portfolios, and business models\u0026mdash;could ultimately create higher-quality revenue and support the next phase of growth.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Disruptor1UP dis2]]\n\u003cp\u003eCompanies that have already advanced on all three dimensions secured the highest quality of revenue and broke away from their peers by measures of financial performance. Progressing on all three dimensions is rare; most companies focus on one dimension to be recognized as an operations champion, product leader, or business-model innovator. The full report looks more deeply at what each type of company can do to excel.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eWhat does it take to win?\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe tailwinds driving the flow control sector will provide ample opportunity for companies equipped with the right enablers to outperform their peers and accrue value. However, companies that maintain the status quo will be left behind as the market changes. With innovation disrupting the sector, the old playbook will no longer suffice. Conversely, capturing value from these innovations will not be trivial. Going forward, companies must address four key imperatives to develop a winning strategy and scale up:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eClose the operating performance gap to free up capital.\u003c/em\u003e New technologies and solutions are critical to success in the new environment. However,\n    technological development requires a significant investment in capabilities, infrastructure, change management, and talent. Flow control companies can free up cash for these investments by looking across the return-on-invested-capital (ROIC) tree for opportunities such as product portfolio and feature optimization, pricing, supply-chain optimization, and sourcing.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eEstablish a pragmatic game plan to use disruptive technologies. \u003c/em\u003eInnovation can be expensive. Disruption 2.0 technologies can help flow control companies improve quality of revenue by focusing across the axes of product innovation, new business models, and operational excellence. However, the associated investments are significant. A pragmatic game plan is necessary to ensure the highest ROIC.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eBroaden the M\u0026amp;A mandate. \u003c/em\u003eTraditionally, M\u0026amp;A activities in flow control have focused on sector consolidation. For companies to pull ahead and capitalize on new trends and Disruption 2.0, they should broaden the focus of their M\u0026amp;A mandate to also fill gaps in technology and capabilities. M\u0026amp;A can provide a faster route to product-portfolio diversification, new business models, and technologies and capabilities such as advanced analytics.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eEstablish robust governance and performance management. \u003c/em\u003eClosing operating-performance gaps and delivering on investments in innovation is a multiyear transformation. Such undertakings field a high risk of going directionless and compromising significant capital. As flow control companies embark on this journey, they should reflect on three questions: Have we defined appropriate near-term milestones that will help us gauge progress against the end-state objectives? Are we \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/the-organization-blog/keys-to-unlocking-great-decision-making\"\u003eagile in our decision making\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;so that we can reprioritize if our initial bets are not successful? Have we reserved sufficient senior-management attention to the cause?\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOverall, flow control companies must keep pace with Industry 4.0, IIoT, and machine learning, and robustly engage with the changing demands of the global market. As innovation disrupts the sector, the old playbook will not suffice. Flow control companies that make the right moves stand to gain significant advantage in an exciting period of growth and disruption.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eDownload\u003c/em\u003e current on your favorite topics"}}}]},"articlesidebar":{"results":[{"mediaID":{"value":"1"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eTo understand the pulse of the sector, we surveyed more than 40 executives in flow control, focusing on their outlook for the sector, upcoming opportunities for growth, and their preparedness to secure these opportunities. We\u0026rsquo;ve distilled the results into four key findings.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e1. Flow control leaders are optimistic about the sector\u0026rsquo;s future\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMore than 80 percent of the executives we surveyed think that flow control performance sentiments have improved in the past year, and almost 60 percent believe the sector will grow faster than GDP (Exhibit 1).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit A]]\n\u003ch3\u003e2. New technologies and geographic expansion will provide new growth opportunities\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThree-quarters of our survey respondents agreed that new technologies offer the biggest opportunities for growth (Exhibit 2). Traditionally, flow control companies have lagged behind in their adoption of technology and reactions to new trends as most companies have been able to thrive on high margins and specialization. Now, however, executives recognize the need to embrace change and make moves in new areas. Growing interest in technology and innovation is also demonstrated by increasing acquisitions of IoT, data analytics, and software start-ups among large flow control companies.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit B]]\n\u003ch3\u003e3. Executives know what they need to do\u0026mdash;but they feel unprepared\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMost executives agreed that they need to expand their offerings, particularly by focusing on smarter products; offer a full solution for their customers; and improve their capabilities by incorporating advanced analytics into their approach. These changes in turn require them to make different operating-model choices so they can be more agile both in their own decision making and in serving customers (Exhibit 3).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit C]]\n\u003cp\u003eWhile executives recognize that they need to take advantage of new opportunities, few feel ready. In our survey, only a small percentage of companies (10 to 15 percent) had made significant progress in developing new operating models and capabilities. More executives (33 percent) responded that they\u0026rsquo;d made significant progress in developing new offerings, but the number is still fairly low given the potential of the opportunities (Exhibit 4).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit D]]\n\u003ch3\u003e4. Focus on short-term investments, lack of a burning platform, and difficulty finding the right talent are proving to be this sector\u0026rsquo;s Achilles\u0026rsquo; heel\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhen asked what\u0026rsquo;s holding them back, executives said the greatest challenge comes from companies\u0026rsquo; reluctance to make bold bets\u0026mdash;28 percent suggested that shorter-term investments are taking a higher priority, 23 percent cited the lack of a burning platform to act quickly, and 19 percent found it difficult to find the right talent to drive the priorities (Exhibit 5).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit E]]"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Sector pulse check: Executive
